org.kiji.mapreduce.kvstore.lib
Class InMemoryMapKeyValueStore<K,V>

java.lang.Object
  org.kiji.mapreduce.kvstore.lib.InMemoryMapKeyValueStore<K,V>
Type Parameters:
K - The type of the key field. Should implement Serializable.
V - The type of the value field. Should implement Serializable.
All Implemented Interfaces:
KeyValueStore<K,V>
@ApiAudience.Public
@ApiStability.Experimental
public final class InMemoryMapKeyValueStore<K,V>
extends Object
implements KeyValueStore<K,V>

KeyValueStore backed entirely by an in-memory map.

This key-value store provides an encapsulated way to pass information to all tasks in a KijiMR job via the key-value store system. This can be useful for things like passing contextual information to Producers that is too ephemeral to store in a KijiTable or file in HDFS (time of day, for example.) A typical usage case for this class is to register an UnconfiguredKeyValueStore in the Producer and mask it with an instance of InMemoryMapKeyValueStore registered with the job builder.

Since the entire contents of the map will be stored in the job's Configuration, copied to all tasks, and held in memory it is not recommended that this class be used for very large amounts of data.

The key and value types of this key value store must be Serializable. Ideally, they should be Java primitive wrappers (e.g. Integer), Strings, or other small objects.

To create a InMemoryMapKeyValueStore you should use builder() to get a builder object. This class has one method, InMemoryMapKeyValueStore.Builder#withMap(Map) which takes as input the Map<K, V> to be used to back the InMemoryMapKeyValueStore.

The contents of this Map are copied when InMemoryMapKeyValueStore.Builder.build() is called; modifications to the map between the calls to Builder#withMap(Map) and InMemoryMapKeyValueStore.Builder.build() will be reflected in the KeyValueStore. Modifications made after the call to build() will not. Thus, all data should be stored in the Map passed to Builder#withMap(Map) before the call to InMemoryMapKeyValueStore.Builder.build(), but it can either be inserted before or between these calls.

As a shortcut, you may use the static method InMemoryMapKeyValueStore#fromMap(Map) to immediately generate a key value store with the contents of the Map argument. Note that the Map is copied immediately and no modifications made to it after the call to get() will be reflected in the InMemoryMapKeyValueStore.

In either case, the copy is a shallow copy, i.e. references to the Objects used as keys and values will be used rather than creating new Objects. As a result, you should be cautious about mutating the Objects used as keys or values, as their state is not locked down until the key value store is serialized.

Constructor Detail

InMemoryMapKeyValueStore

public InMemoryMapKeyValueStore()
Reflection-only constructor. Used only for reflection. You should create InMemoryMapKeyValueStore instances by using a builder or the factory method InMemoryMapKeyValueStore#fromMap(Map).

Method Detail

builder

public static InMemoryMapKeyValueStore.Builder builder()
Creates a new InMemoryMapKeyValueStore.Builder instance that can be used to make an InMemoryMapKeyValueStore.

Returns:
the builder.

fromMap

public static <K,V> InMemoryMapKeyValueStore<K,V> fromMap(Map<K,V> map)
Factory method that returns an InMemoryMapKeyValueStore instance. This makes a shallow copy of the map. Future modifications to the map passed into this call will not be reflected in the KeyValueStore, but changes to the key or value Objects will be.

Type Parameters:
K - The type of the key field. Should implement Serializable.
V - The type of the value field. Should implement Serializable.
Parameters:
map - the map containing the data for the InMemoryMapKeyValueStore.
Returns:
An InMemoryMapKeyValueStore instance.
